seg.seg: ... she has come to us. ... not ... sorrow of the mind ...
... we shall be zealous [so that] he who is going on the road of the antaradvīpa ...
... 1 || The yakṣa Agnikeśa says: || in the [tune] nauṣaññe-taruṇadi(vākarne ||)
... his compassion. He is confused by the delusion of their sorrows.
... with faith (/ compassion?) he says: || in the [tune] nauṣaññe-nāṭakäṣṣene || «Taste ...
... he blocks (/ fills up?) some mixtures/applications. In a harsh way you are holding him ...
... With a lovely gaze he drinks as it were that sorrow of theirs. ...
... so that (?) I go to see him [and] yo console [him] in his sorrow ...
... they cried out with loud voice and began to ...
... the king of ... is hit by a poisonous arrow in the heart. With a great roar ...
... very much. In separate ways you show [your] form like a parre. To be seen ...
... may I take [this] burden of sorrow of theirs. May I even stay ...
...beings (?). Noble wisdom, good forms [and] splendour. All ...
... he sent down into the human world. Virtuous ...

p.note: nauṣaññe taruṇadi(vākar) in line a3 will have the same metre as taruṇadivākar, that is a, b, d: 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 and c: 5 ¦ 5 (281). Indeed, : ceṃts läklentaṣṣe trikau traikesa : in line a4 is 5 ¦ 5 and must therefore be pāda c.

[[Broomhead I]]: 169 translates:

a1 It has come for us [but] not ... : The sorrow of the spirit ...

a2 We shall be zealous [so] that he who is travelling on the road to the middle island ...

a3 The yakṣa Agnikeśe speaks: || In Nauṣaññe Taruṇadivākar metre ||

a4 "I shall see his compassion". Confused by the dazzling of pain,

a5 [he] speaks full of belief. || In Nauṣaññe Nāṭakäṣṣe metre || "The taste [of] ... "

a6 And somehow restrained. Having gripped [his] temple violently that one [then] ...

a7 [And] with tender gaze he drinks from him, as it were, this sorrow. [This] sor[row] ...

a8 ... his ... ceased.

b2 I shall go myself to see this one [and] to comfort him in his sorrow.

b3 With a great voice they released [their] voice[s] [and] they began to ...

b4 The elephant-king pierced through [his] heart by the poisonous arrow, witha great noise ...

b5 very much. In different ways like a chameleon he produces colour ... to look at ...

b6 From this one I shall [take] the burden of sorrow. May I stand until ...

b7 Nobility, knowledge, beautiful form [and] splendour, he [has] all.

b8 sent him down into the human world full of virtues.

a4: on the left, 4 akṣaras for vākar || are missing, and 34 more syllables according to the metre. Thus, approximately 40 akṣaras are in total missing on the left. Probably, the string hole space covered this line, so that in lines 1-3 and 6-8 even more akṣaras may be missing.

According to [[Broomhead I]]: 168 "[w]ritten in very large ductus, and clearly preserved, it is the right edge of an eight line manuscript."

a5 (takarṣ)käññesa, (añmālaṣ)käññesa
a6 raitwenta, pwenta

Metrical analysis:

nauṣaññe taruṇadi(vākar) in line a3 will have the same metre as taruṇadivākar, that is a, b, d: 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 and c: 5 ¦ 5 ([[Adams, DoT]]: 281). Indeed, : ceṃts läklentaṣṣe trikau traikesa : in line a4 is 5 ¦ 5 and must therefore be pāda c.


– pāda missing completely – [1a] (19 syllables missing)
[a4] /// (la)kau karuṃ cwī : [1b] (15 syllables missing)
ceṃts läklentaṣṣe ¦ trikau traikesa : [1c]
– pāda missing completely – [1d] (19 syllables missing)

cf. the metre in a5 is also found in [[IOL Toch 36]] a5.

Beginning and end of the strophes in b5-7 cannot be established, but the metre may be 4 x 5 ¦ 7:

[b5] /// māka :
waiptār klautkentsa ¦ ere slaṅtar parre ra :
lkātsi[b6]
/// ·u yāmar ¦ ceṃts läkleṣṣe perpette :
stamoym eṃ[b7](ṣke)
/// -lm· :
klyomñe aiśamñe ¦ ersna krenta peñīyo :
po su
